description: From Anglo-Norman apescher, rare variant of Old French empescher, from Latin impedicō.

verbs.description: appeach (third-person singular simple present appeaches, present participle appeaching, simple past and past participle appeached)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To charge (someone) with a crime; to impeach. [15th–17th c.]
examples: “ […]  When the riches are equal, we might say that the luckier side wins, as if by tossing a coin. Now, are you two sure, if you did appeach Queen Guenever of treason, that your side would be the luckier one?”
